dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, there's this really fascinating, um, almost contradictory situation unfolding with Boeing right now. On one hand, they're looking for taxpayer-funded aid, but on the other, they've actually seen some pretty big wins.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, there's this really fascinating, um, almost contradictory situation unfolding with Boeing right now. On one hand, they're looking for taxpayer-funded aid, but on the other, they've actually seen some pretty big wins.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The plane maker and its suppliers are facing a mounting financial crisis after Boeing halted production of the 737 MAX in January.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's wild, right? Like, they produced all these 737 MAX planes, 400 of them, that were grounded, but now, with, uh, COVID waning, airlines suddenly want them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's wild, right? Like, they produced all these seven hundred thirty seven meters A X planes, four hundred of them, that were grounded, but now, with, uh, C O V I D waning, airlines suddenly want them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Their stress has been compounded by the sudden decline in business of their airline customers as coronavirus has spread worldwide, raising the specter that many carriers will delay delivery of planes, slowing Boeings recovery once the 737 MAX returns to service.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But what really jumped out at me was Boeing's own statement about the aid. They said financial support would go towards executive bonuses, *and* the broader health of their competitors. [chuckles]
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But what really jumped out at me was Boeing's own statement about the aid. They said financial support would go towards executive bonuses, and the broader health of their competitors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Boeing stressed in a statement that financial support for the company would flow through to its suppliers and support the broader health of the U.S. aerospace industry.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, they *said* that? Like, openly? That's, um, bold. And then remember Trump's initial take? He was like, "Punish Boeing, we won't be helping them."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, they said that? Like, openly? That's, um, bold. And then remember Trump's initial take? He was like, Punish Boeing, we won't be helping them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Earlier in the day, President Trump said at a press conference that support would be forthcoming. I think we have to protect Boeing, he said. Obviously when the airlines aren't doing well then Boeing is not going to be doing well. So we'll be helping Boeing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right! Which felt so out of sync, especially considering, uh, just days later, Boeing's stock is soaring, up 44%!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! Which felt so out of sync, especially considering, uh, just days later, Boeing's stock is soaring, up forty four percent!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Concern has been rising over the past week that Boeing may face a liquidity crisis, with its stock plummeting 44% over that span to close Tuesday at $124.14, its lowest point since 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know! And S&P actually *upgraded* their debt! They're now expecting like, $11 to $12 billion in cash flow this year, not a negative. It's… confusing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! And S and P actually upgraded their debt! They're now expecting like, eleven to twelve billion in cash flow this year, not a negative. It's... confusing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Monday, Standard & Poors downgraded Boeing debt two notches to BBB from A-, citing a significantly worsened cash flow outlook over the next two years. The ratings agency now expects an outflow of $11 billion to $12 billion this year, down from a prior expectation of positive cash flow of $2 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. They already spent $13.8 billion from a credit line they just arranged. So, like, do they actually *need* that $60 billion they were hinting at?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. They already spent thirteen point eight billion from a credit line they just arranged. So, like, do they actually need that sixty billion they were hinting at?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chicago-based company disclosed in an SEC filing after the close of trading that it had fully drawn $13.8 billion from a line of credit it had arranged just last month. ... The statement didnt specify how much of the $60 billion the company believes it needs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Good question. An analyst even said, you know, giving them *insufficient* liquidity might be better, given their existing $41 billion in debt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Good question. An analyst even said, you know, giving them insufficient liquidity might be better, given their existing forty one billion in debt.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The government should provide sufficient liquidity to keep Boeing going, Robert Stallard, an analyst with Vertical Research Partners, said in a client note, but with total debt of $41 billion already, more loans will bring serious risks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, because then they're not, like, unburdened and able to just compete super aggressively without a real need for it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, because then they're not, like, unburdened and able to just compete super aggressively without a real need for it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And let's not forget the, uh, share buybacks from the past decade. That's a huge point of contention for critics. Enriching executives, shareholders…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And let's not forget the, uh, share buybacks from the past decade. That's a huge point of contention for critics. Enriching executives, shareholders...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Critics of the prospect of so much taxpayer money going to Boeing and the airlines have focused on the billions of dollars worth of share buybacks that they have made over the past decade, enriching executives and their shareholders.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. People are asking, "Why bail out companies that, um, enriched their shareholders when times were good?" It’s a guaranteed failure if there are no conditions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. People are asking, Why bail out companies that, um, enriched their shareholders when times were good? It's a guaranteed failure if there are no conditions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But then, you look at the sheer scale of the industry. Boeing at the bottom of a pyramid of 17,000 aerospace firms, 2.5 million workers, 750,000 airline employees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then, you look at the sheer scale of the industry. Boeing at the bottom of a pyramid of seventeen thousand aerospace firms, two point five million workers, seven hundred fifty thousand airline employees.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Boeing stands at the apex of a pyramid of 17,000 aerospace firms that employ 2.5 million workers while U.S. airlines directly employ 75o,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's a huge sector, so the impact is massive. That's why people like Sara Nelson from the Flight Attendants union are really pushing for conditions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a huge sector, so the impact is massive. That's why people like Sara Nelson from the Flight Attendants union are really pushing for conditions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sara Nelson, the president of the Association of Flight Attendants-CWA, vowed Monday that airlines wouldnt make out as easy as the banks did in 2008. The airline industry didnt cause the pandemic and money should come with significant conditions to help workers and keep planes flying, not enrich shareholders or pad executive bonuses, she said on Twitter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. No bonuses, no buybacks, maintain payroll, worker board seats. Like, actual commitments, not just, um, a blank cheque like the bank bailouts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. No bonuses, no buybacks, maintain payroll, worker board seats. Like, actual commitments, not just, um, a blank cheque like the bank bailouts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Airlines must commit to maintaining payroll. It means no bonuses, no buybacks, & no breaking union contracts in bankruptcy. Companies should commit to pay a min $15 wage and board seats for workers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's not just about keeping them afloat, it's about ensuring this aid actually benefits the workers and, uh, the long-term health of the industry, not just, you know, the top brass.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's not just about keeping them afloat, it's about ensuring this aid actually benefits the workers and, uh, the long-term health of the industry, not just, you know, the top brass.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a really complex balance, and it'll be interesting to see what conditions, if any, ultimately stick.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a really complex balance, and it'll be interesting to see what conditions, if any, ultimately stick.
